I have mixed feelings about this game, but overall it's a good buy. This comes from an old Unreal 3 engine mod made retail. When first released the graphics were not top notch, but they aren't ugly. The animations are well done and when you reload it feels like you are actually reloading; not that Modern Warface "click clack shoot" crap. Teamwork is not required. It is needed. My only other player Online Co-op is Left 4 Dead, but trust me when I say that going solo will bite back hard. To clarify, for every player that joins a map, the enemy becomes stronger by X times so you'd better work together or be ready to watch the stare at the screen again. Then again, reaching the Patriarch is more satifaction to make up for any fuck ups. Enough talk! Buy the game, pick your perk and for the love of god play on normal the first time. Oh and go read this great guide from the Killing Floor forums. It might just save you. http://forums.tripwireinteractive.com/showthread.php?t=31487

Классная игра.

Short Version:

Pros:
+ Highly replayable
+ Good enemy and weapon variety
+ Great soundtrack
+ Huge amount of maps
+ Friendly community (used to be better, but still not as toxic as most online communities)
+ Super challenging
+ A lot of personality and charm
+ Gun impact feels and sounds great (specially headshots)
+ Different classes you can level up
+ Workshop support (more skins, maps, etc)
+ Devs made sure all achievements were obtainable after the game stopped receiving updates (event exclusive achievements, for example)

Cons:
- Unfriendly to new players
- Gameplay has some limitations
- Some achievements are horrendous
- Perk progress is a bit slow

"Long" Version:

[u]Killing Floor[/u] is a co-op first person shooter brought to us by Tripwire Interactive. You are part of a 6 man squad and must kill all enemies every wave until you reach the final boss.

Bits of story are scattered throughout the base maps, however, with the inclusion of new content (survival and objective maps) we get a more in-depth look at this world. Basically, there's an evil organization called Horzine that created monstrous specimens (ZEDs) and it is up to you and your squad to stop them. It is nothing amazing, but it is serviceable - it feels like a low budget 80s slasher movie.

There are two types of gameplay - "Killing Floor" and "Objective Mode". 
In "Killing Floor", you must clear waves of specimens that gradually grow more difficult, until you reach the final boss. With each kill and wave, the player gets money to spend in the shop, where they can purchase armor, ammo and new weapons.
In "Objective Mode", you must complete a vast array of tasks, whilst also being attacked by ZEDs.
Both modes are enjoyable, however, I still prefer the original wave-based mode - the objective mode requires you to move around a lot and, on harder difficulties, it seems a bit overwhelming.

The amount of content in [u]Killing Floor[/u] is simply amazing; sure, some cosmetics are DLC but all players get access to all maps and that is a good business practice in my book.
The game has 7 perks (think of them as classes), each specializing in a different area - there is the Field Medic class that focuses on healing and tanking, the Firebug who deals damage over time, the Sharpshooter who focuses on bigger, more powerful threats with unmatched precision, the Commando that specializes in killing small, more numerous ZEDs, etc. The player can level these up, each needing a certain amount of damage dealt with certain kinds of weapons in most cases. There are some exceptions, where you must heal your teammates or kill specific types of ZEDs instead. While getting the level up notification feels great, grinding damage for it to happen is not as fun. It certainly is not a total grind-fest; but leveling up classes you do not like to get an achievement might prove very bothersome, as it does take quite a while.
Each perk has a certain amount of weapons it excels at - Support Specialists, for example, have a vast number of shotguns at their disposal and deal extra damage with them. Everyone can, however, use any weapon - though effectiveness will vary.
There are around 50 weapons in the game, promoting a lot of experimentation. All of them have their pros and cons, however, learning which one suits each playstyle better feels great.

ZED variety is also good. The specimens range from the numerous clots (pretty much slow, weaker zombies) to towering Fleshpounds (gigantic, Hulk-like specimens that require tons of damage to go down) - each of them poses a threat and requires a different approach; a clot might be easy to kill, however, if he grabs you, all other specimens will close in on you; a scrake, for example, is better dealt with with a single powerful headshot - weaker weapons will only anger him, making him charge your team and most likely getting a person or two killed. Some nullify grenades, some are invisible... The list goes on. The player should never feel safe and overconfident, failure is always a possibility and it only takes a single mistake, like being out of position, to ruin a match.

There are almost 30 official maps in [u]Killing Floor[/u] - farms, offices, hospitals, amusement parks (rightfully called Abusement Park), castles, space stations; this game has it all! They do have a lot of invisible walls, as you cannot climb most short fences or cars - that is one of the most obvious gameplay limitations; however, after playing it for a bit, I grew used to it. 
It is frustrating, however, how little mobility you get. Your character moves very slowly in general, only getting a minor speed boost by equipping a knife or choosing a faster class.

While freedom of movement around the maps and character speed might be slightly annoying, these shortcomings are easily countered by everything else. You have a huge variety of options regarding maps, classes and weapons in a game that offers unmatched replay value and a truly challenging experience (some might say the difficulty borders on unfair).
Each map can be completed on five different difficulty settings (and must be if you want to get all achievements). However, the lower difficulty achievements do not unlock when you complete the highest difficulty one - which is unfortunate; I managed to finish all "Hell on Earth" achievements and still had to go back to finish maps on "Normal" and "Hard". Each map takes around 30/45 minutes to complete - with an ever present possibility of failure, having to start over.
[u]Killing Floor[/u] also features Workshop support; a ton of extra maps and skins are available for free, increasing the replay value indefinitely.


Now that I have (finally) finished talking about the gameplay, it is time to move to [u]Killing Floor[/u]'s audio.
The sound is great in this game. One of the many things I love about it is its personality and charm - something I feel is severely lacking in [u]Killing Floor 2[/u]. That is where the voice acting comes in. Is it good? No! It is actually quite bad. It is one of those "some bad is good" sort of deals. Most playable characters are voiced by the same guy and have the same lines - it is hilarious! They are all stereotypically british and say things like "I'm trying to heal you, not shag you" or "You're all fur-coat, no knickers b*tches". [spoiler][url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dP4qxRkhUF4] Here! [/url][/spoiler] The game embraces its absurdity and never takes itself too seriously.
While the voice acting is of the "so bad it's good" variety, the rest of the sound is actually really good. Guns and explosions sound amazing; getting a headshot with a shotgun sound crunchy, powerful and visceral.
The soundtrack is also great - I usually do not like metal but the music just gets me here. It gets you in the mood to kill some ZEDs. It is loud, it is over the top, it is perfect.

Graphics-wise... The game is definitely not a looker. That being said, I've been playing [u]Killing Floor[/u] since 2011 (back when [u]Killing Floor[/u] and [u]The Binding of Isaac[/u] were the only games I could run on my horrible laptop - maybe that is why they hold a special space in my heart) and the graphics do not really bother me. If you check the store's screenshots you might get a good idea of how the game looks.

When it comes to the community, I must say, [u]Killing Floor[/u] has a pretty decent one. I have made numerous friends while playing it and we still keep in touch and play it from time to time. It is a fully co-op experience, meaning there is little to no room for toxicity (even though it has increased over the years). The community is still active and usually very welcoming to new players - just ask for help and you will most likely make a friend or two.

I adore [u]Killing Floor[/u] - great gameplay, personality and amounts of content. It has not aged particularly well graphics-wise but that is ok. As usual, it is better with friends!

Final score: 8.5 out of 10.

Game of the Month: JANUARY

Though it's often been compared to the likes of Left 4 Dead, Killing Floor should not be dismissed as a knock-off or inferior game.

Sporting challenging hordes of the undead, strong weapons, and finely-tuned levels, Killing Floor is a cooperative survival game where you have no objective or goals. Just survive.

From the insane amount of enemies thrown at you, and the extreme difficulty brought by the beefier enemies, the player develops a strong sense of cooperation and dependency on their teammates, and vice versa; you could play the game yourself, but it's 5x more fun to play with several other monster-hunters.

It should be considered a league of its own when talking zombie survival games, and highly recommend this game to both the hardcores and the casuals.

Хороший кооперативный шутер-выживание с элементами РПГ. Стоит не дорого (на распродажах скидка 75%), веселое времяпровождение с друзьями или в онлайне, есть прокачка уровней, разные перки, несколько сложностей и даже босс - что нужно еще для веселья. И самое главное это хорошее комьюнити - мутаторы (моды), выделенные сервера, оружие, новые перки и многое другое. Благодаря мододелам игра все еще живет несмотря на год выпуска.

Killing Floor really is a magnificent beast of a game. There's so many little things about it that I love. The guns feel AMAZING. Something about them is just absolutely spot on. The British dialogue and voice commands are hilarious, me and my buddies have been quoting them off and on through life for a few years now ("Up stairs to bedtime, children", "Cheers, big ears!", etc.). TripWire is constantly adding more content to the game too, which is great. The more friends you have who are willing to play this with you the better it is, though. I've seen some lackluster reviews in the past and I think this is mostly due to the online experience not being quite as strategic and badass as holding off the hoards with a group of your buddies. Plus, the hardest difficulty is so damned challenging, it's really easy to get hooked trying to beat a map over and over (and you always make it SO close too before those four fleshies spawn in your face on the last wave with 30 zeds left on the clock).
Amazing

Essentually a Quake or UT mod that thought it was good enough to be sold on its own. Protip: its not. One of the most boring games I've had the displeasure of being talked into buying in a long time.

Major mistakes: 

1. Very little variety to the game. Kill shit wave after wave and survive. Unless you have Autism, once each map and class you'll be bored.

2. Perks take forever to grind. KF is not an mmo, stop putting in time sinks like it is one, you have no cash shop you are trying to sell so its uneccessary.

3. No cross hairs, I don't care about "it gives challenge" bullshit. Shit is annoying.
>2012
>not having crosshairs

Now for something positive.

1. Forced Teamwork on higher difficulties. I do like any game to some degree that you can't derp your way through. I'll give KF props for that.

I can't recommend this game at its price, I can't recommend it on sale, I can't recommend it for free.
